FacilityName: John Taylor Fertilizers Company, Inc - Dixon

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Accidental Release Prevention Policies

The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System and Aqueous Ammonia Storage System.  The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The primary activity at the facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 21,800 gallon (gal) storage tank (bullet tank) at the site.  The facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity to 85 percent (%) of the fill capacity for both covered processes.  The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 95,430 pounds (lbs).  Aqua ammonia (24% of ammonia by weight) is stored in two 21,250 gal above-ground storage tanks at the site.  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 136,820 lbs.  The total quantity of ammonia present in the aqua ammonia, based on 24% active ingredient by weight, is 22,400 lbs.



Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Worst-Case/Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary

Per CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario have been defined for each process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Risk Considerations

Although the storage of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the facility has recognized

these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

Additionally, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an anhydrous or aqueous ammonia release.  The facility utilizes a pressure relief valve, manual shutoffs, and emergency shutdown systems.



Accidental Release Prevention Program

As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 2 and Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia.  Prevention elements for each program are listed in Table 1 below.

 

List of Prevention Program Elements 

Aqueous Ammonia Storage Prevention Program 2 Elements

   ?  Safety Information

   ?  Hazard Review

   ?  Operating Procedures

   ?  Training

   ?  Maintenance

   ?  Compliance Audits

   ?  Incident Investigation

Anhydrous Ammonia Storage Prevention Program 3 Elements

   ?  Process Safety Information

   ?  Process Hazard Analysis

   ?  Operating Procedures

   ?  Training

   ?  Mechanical Integrity

   ?  Management of Change

   ?  Pre-Startup Safety Review

   ?  Compliance Audits

   ?  Incident Investigation

   ?  Employee Participation

   ?  Hot Work Permit

   ?  Contractors



Five-Year Accident History

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  



External Events Analysis

Pursuant to the requirements of CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, ?2745.7(q), general events external to the plant were addressed by the April 2009 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the anhydrous ammonia pr

ocess.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions:

   1)    The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA ?2760.2 or Hazard Review (HR) ?2755.2.  During the PHA, a broad list of external events was considered by the Study Team.  The external events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact.

   2)    The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered.  If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the Administering Agency (AA) to determine what is required.  If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.

The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.

   3)    For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 

     ?    The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

     ?    Major hazards identified;

     ?    Process controls in use;

     ?    Mitigation systems in use;

     ?    Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,

     ?    Changes since the last HR or PHA



Refer to Section 7.4 of the RMPe*Submit printout for the required PHA information.

   4)    The date of the most recent field verification that equipment is installed and maintained as designed.



The most recent field verification of equipment was conducted in April 2009 and included the major equipment of the process.



Emergency Response Program

Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  The Wilbur-Ellis Dixon Facility will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders.  The facility has filed a Busines

s Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.  An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220 is in place.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The PHA study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the April 15, 2009 PHA Report.  Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed in a timely manner and all corrective actions taken will be recorded in the Action Tracking Log that can be found in Appendix A of CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.
